Description: Following a public comment period, the Federal Trade Commission approved a final order resolving FTC allegations that Apple Inc. unfairly charged consumers for in-app purchases incurred by children without their parents' consent. Under the settlement, by March 31, 2014, Apple must change its billing practices to ensure that it has obtained express, informed consent from consumers before charging them for in-app purchases. Apple also must provide full refunds, totaling a minimum of $32.5 million, to consumers who were billed for in-app purchases that were incurred by children and were either accidental or not authorized by the consumer.

Court: Superior Court of State of California, County of San Diego

Description: This case involved allegations that high-tech companies conspired not to hire each other's employees, thus suppressing salary levels. Apple, Google, Intel and Adobe Systems together agreed to settle the matter for $415 million. The settlement did not specify how much each of the companies would pay. Here we assume the total was equally divided among the four.
Private Litigation Case Title: In Re: High-Tech Employee Antitrust Litigation

Description: Apple came to an agreement with the Attorney General and the National Federation of the Blind to provide blind consumers full and equal access to Apple's iTunes and iTunes U. As part of the agreement Apple agreed to contribute $250,000 to the Massachusetts Commission for the Blind.

A group of states sued several leading book publishers and Apple Inc. alleging they conspired to fix the price of electronic books. The publishers agreed to pay a total of $166 million while Apple ended up paying $450 million.
Private Litigation Case Title: Texas et al. v. Penguin Group et al.

Description: A coalition of over 30 other attorneys general announced a $113 million settlement with Apple, Inc. regarding its 2016 decision to throttle consumers' iPhone speeds in order to address unexpected shutdowns in some iPhones.

Apple agreed to pay $450,000 in settlement of allegations it violated state hazardous waste laws by failing to keep required records, failing to label waste correctly, failing to provide plans and financial assurance for closure at its Cupertino facility, and setting up and running a new electronic waste shredding facility in Sunnyvale without informing the Department of Toxic Substance Control and without complying with waste regulations.
Agency: California Department of Toxic Substances Control
